lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Cassandra.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Cassandra.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
**Cassandra** is a CLI-based task manager app designed to help users manage their daily tasks effectively.
Add a simple todo task to your list.
Add a task with a deadline.
(date fmt:  dd-mm-yyyy or dd-mm-yyyy HHmm format or <day-of-the-week> or next <day-of-the-week>) (works with HHmm)
Add an event task with a start and end time.
(date fmt:  dd-mm-yyyy or dd-mm-yyyy HHmm format or <day-of-the-week> or next <day-of-the-week>) (works with HHmm)
Displays all tasks currently in your list.
Mark a task as complete by specifying its index.
Unmark a task (set it as incomplete) by specifying its index.
Find tasks with descriptions similar to the provided prompt.
* Command class responsible for adding a deadline task to the task list.
* It parses the input string for the task name and deadline and creates a new deadline task.
* The task is then added to the task list and saved to storage.
* @param tasks The TaskList object where the new deadline task will be added.
* @param input The user input containing the deadline details.
* Executes the command by parsing the input for a deadline task and adding it to the task list.
* @throws InvalidDeadlineFormatException If the deadline format is invalid.
* @throws InvalidDateFormatException If the date format is invalid.
public void execute() throws InvalidDeadlineFormatException, InvalidDateFormatException {
throw new InvalidDeadlineFormatException("Sorry, deadline entered has the wrong format");
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task: \n " + newDeadline.toString());
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Command class responsible for adding an event task to the task list.
* It parses the input string for the event name, start time, and end time,
* and creates a new event task that is added to the task list and saved to storage.
* @param tasks The TaskList object where the new event task will be added.
* @param input The user input containing the event details.
* Executes the command by parsing the input for an event task and adding it to the task list.
* @throws InvalidEventFormatException If the event format is invalid.
* @throws InvalidDateFormatException If the date format is invalid.
public void execute() throws InvalidEventFormatException, InvalidDateFormatException {
throw new InvalidEventFormatException("Sorry, event entered has the wrong format");
Event newEvent = new Event(eventTaskName, fromDate, toDate);
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this event: \n " + newEvent.toString());
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Command class responsible for adding a to-do task to the task list.
* It parses the input string for the task name and creates a new to-do task.
* The task is then added to the task list and saved to storage.
* @param tasks The TaskList object where the new to-do task will be added.
* @param input The user input containing the to-do details.
* Executes the command by parsing the input for a to-do task and adding it to the task list.
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task: \n " + newTodo.toString());
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* The Command interface represents an abstraction for various commands
* that can be executed on the task list. Each command class implementing
* this interface should provide its own implementation of the execute method.
* Implementing classes must define the behavior of the command.
* Command class responsible for deleting a task from the task list.
* It removes the task at the specified index from the task list and updates the storage.
* @param tasks The TaskList object from which the task will be deleted.
* @param taskIndex The index of the task to be deleted.
* Executes the command by deleting the task at the specified index from the task list.
* @throws TaskNotFoundException If the task index is invalid or out of bounds.
throw new TaskNotFoundException("Sorry, no task found");
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Command class responsible for handling the exit operation.
* It stops the task list execution and prints a goodbye message.
* @param tasks The TaskList object used to control the running state.
* Executes the command by stopping the running state of the task list.
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Command class responsible for finding tasks that match a given prompt.
* It searches the task list for tasks that contain the prompt and displays the results.
* @param tasks The TaskList object where tasks will be searched.
* @param input The user input containing the prompt to search for.
* Executes the command by searching for tasks that match the given prompt.
* @throws NoTaskContainsMatchingPromptException If no tasks match the prompt or if the prompt is empty.
throw new NoTaskContainsMatchingPromptException("Sorry! Please enter a prompt to be searched, use help to learn more");
String result = "Here are the matching tasks in your list: \n";
throw new NoTaskContainsMatchingPromptException("Sorry! We couldn't find any task that contains " + prompt);
* Command class responsible for displaying help instructions to the user.
* It invokes the UI component to show the available commands and their usage.
* @param ui The UI object that will be used to display help instructions.
* Executes the command by displaying the help instructions.
* Command class responsible for listing all the tasks in the task list.
* It prints out all the tasks currently in the task list.
* @param tasks The TaskList object containing tasks to be listed.
* Executes the command by listing all tasks in the task list.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* The MarkCommand class represents a command to mark a task as completed in the task list.
* It updates the task as completed, saves the changes, and handles related exceptions.
* @param tasks     The task list containing tasks.
* @param taskIndex The index of the task to be marked as completed.
* Executes the command to mark a task as completed.
* @throws TaskNotFoundException       If the specified task index does not exist in the list.
* @throws TaskAlreadyMarkedException  If the task is already marked as completed.
public void execute() throws TaskNotFoundException, TaskAlreadyMarkedException {
throw new TaskNotFoundException("Sorry, no task found");
throw new TaskAlreadyMarkedException("Task has already been marked complete");
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* The UnmarkCommand class represents a command to mark a task as not completed in the task list.
* It updates the task as incomplete, saves the changes, and handles related exceptions.
* @param tasks     The task list containing tasks.
* @param taskIndex The index of the task to be marked as incomplete.
* Executes the command to mark a task as incomplete.
* @throws TaskNotFoundException        If the specified task index does not exist in the list.
* @throws TaskAlreadyUnmarkedException If the task is already marked as incomplete.
public void execute() throws TaskNotFoundException, TaskAlreadyUnmarkedException {
throw new TaskNotFoundException("Sorry, no task found");
throw new TaskAlreadyUnmarkedException("Task has already been marked incomplete");
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
* The Deadline class represents a task of type "Deadline", which includes a specific deadline.
* It inherits from the Task class.
* Constructs a new Deadline object with the specified task name and deadline time.

* Returns a formatted string of the deadline time.
* Overrides the default toString method to provide a specific format for Deadline tasks.
* @return The string representation of the Deadline task.
* Returns the string format of the Deadline task to be written to a file.
* @return The writable string format of the Deadline task.
* The Event class represents a task of type "Event", which includes a start time and an end time.
* It inherits from the Task class.
* Constructs a new Event object with the specified task name, start time, and end time.
* @param taskName The name of the Event task.
* @param fromTime The start time of the event.
* @param toTime The end time of the event.
public Event(String taskName, LocalDateTime fromTime, LocalDateTime toTime) {
* Returns a formatted string of the event's start time.
* Returns a formatted string of the event's end time.
* Overrides the default toString method to provide a specific format for Event tasks.
* @return The string representation of the Event task.
* Returns the string format of the Event task to be written to a file.
* @return The writable string format of the Event task.
* The Task class represents a generic task with a task name and a completed status.
* This is the base class for specific types of tasks like Todo, Deadline, and Event.
* Constructs a new Task object with the specified task name and initializes it as incomplete.
* @param taskName The name of the task.
* Returns the status icon based on whether the task is completed.
* @return "X" if the task is completed, otherwise " ".
* Returns the string representation of the task, including its completion status and task name.
* @return The string representation of the task.
* Returns the string format of the task to be written to a file.
* @return The writable string format of the task.
* The Todo class represents a task of type "Todo"
* It inherits from the Task class.
* Constructs a new Todo object with the specified task name.
* @param taskName The name of the Todo task.
* Overrides the default toString method to provide a specific format for Todo tasks.
* @return The string representation of the Todo task.
* Returns the string format of the Todo task to be written to a file.
* @return The writable string format of the Todo task.
* Parser class that contains utility methods for parsing user input and date/time strings,
* and mapping input commands to the corresponding Command classes.
// Map for associating day strings to DayOfWeek enum values
static final Map<String, DayOfWeek> DAY_MAP = Map.of(
* Retrieves user input from the console.
* @return A trimmed string containing the user's input.
* Splits the user input into an array of command arguments.
* @param input The raw input string entered by the user.
* @return An array of strings representing the individual command arguments.
* Gets the next occurrence of a specified day of the week.
* @param dayOfWeek The day of the week to find.
* @return A LocalDate representing the next occurrence of the specified day.
* Parses a string input to determine a deadline date and time.
* Supports natural language (e.g., "monday", "next monday") and specific date/time formats.
* @param by The user input specifying the deadline.
* @return A LocalDateTime object representing the parsed deadline.
* @throws InvalidDeadlineFormatException if the input does not match an expected format.
public static LocalDateTime parseDateTime(String by) throws InvalidDeadlineFormatException {
// Regex to match inputs like "next monday 1600" or "wednesday 1400"
// If only day without time (e.g., "monday" or "next monday")
return LocalDateTime.of(getNextDayOfWeek(dayOfWeek), LocalTime.of(0, 0)); // Set default time as 12 AM
// If user provided date and time
return LocalDateTime.of(parsedDate, LocalTime.of(0, 0));  // Default time 12:00 AM
throw new InvalidDateFormatException("Sorry, the date format is incorrect. Use dd-mm-yyyy or dd-mm-yyyy HHmm format or <day-of-the-week> or next <day-of-the-week>.");
throw new InvalidDateFormatException("Sorry, the date format is incorrect. Use dd-MM-yyyy or dd-MM-yyyy HHmm format or <day-of-the-week> or next <day-of-the-week>.");
* Parses a string in the format 'dd-MM-yyyy-HH-mm' into a LocalDateTime object.
* @param dateString The string representing the date and time.
* @return A LocalDateTime object parsed from the input string.
* @throws InvalidDateFormatException if the input string does not match the expected format.
throw new InvalidDateFormatException("Invalid date format. Please use 'dd-MM-yyyy-HH-mm'.");
* Parses the user's input into a corresponding command based on the input command keyword.
* @param input The user's raw input string.
* @param commandArgs The parsed command arguments from the input.
* @param ui The UI instance used to interact with the user.
* @param tasks The TaskList instance containing the tasks to be managed.
* @return A Command object representing the user's input command.
* @throws NoCommandException If no command is provided in the input.
* @throws InvalidCommandException If the input command is not recognized.
public static Command parse(String input, String[] commandArgs, UI ui, TaskList tasks) throws NoCommandException {
throw new NoCommandException("Sorry, you haven't entered any command.");
default -> throw new InvalidCommandException("Sorry, unknown command.");
* Storage class that handles reading and writing tasks to and from a file.
* Manages the creation of directories and files, and supports storing tasks as a list.

* @param directoryPath The path to the directory where the file will be stored.
* @param fileName The name of the file to store tasks.
* Creates the directory if it does not exist.
* If the directory creation fails, an error message is displayed.
throw new IOException("Could not create directory");

throw new CassandraException("An error occurred while reading from the file.");

* The TaskList class manages a collection of Task objects and interacts with the Storage class for persistence.
* It supports functionality to manage the state of the task list and handle tasks during runtime.

* @param storage The Storage object responsible for file operations related to task saving and loading.

* The UI class handles user interface interactions by providing methods for displaying messages, help instructions, and task-related prompts.
* It also includes methods to print introduction art and error messages.
* Draws a line of dashes to visually separate sections in the UI.
* Displays the introductory ASCII art for the Cassandra application.
* Displays the introduction section, including a separator, ASCII art, and a welcome message for the Cassandra app.
System.out.println(" What can I do for you?");
* Displays help instructions to guide users on the available commands in the Cassandra app.
* It explains how to add tasks, list them, mark/unmark tasks, and other key features.
System.out.println("Welcome to Cassandra - Your Task Manager App!");
System.out.println("Here are the commands you can use:");
System.out.println("   Example: todo Read a book");
System.out.println("   Displays all tasks currently in your list.");

* Displays an error message for exceptions caught during application runtime.
* The Cassandra class is the main class for the task management application.
* It manages user input, parses commands, and interacts with other components like TaskList, Storage, and UI.
* It initializes the UI, Storage, and TaskList components.
* If there is an issue loading tasks from the storage file, it catches the exception and initializes an empty task list.
* Starts the Cassandra task management application.
* It displays the introduction and runs a loop that processes user input until the user exits the app.
Command c = Parser.parse(userInput, commandArgs, ui, tasks);
* The main entry point for the Cassandra application.
* It creates an instance of the Cassandra class and starts the application by calling the run method.
